Name: Access-Phenomenal Distinction
Description: A theoretical framework distinguishing between consciousness that is accessible for report and reasoning (A-consciousness) and raw subjective experience (P-consciousness).

Name: Attentional Models of Consciousness
Description: A class of theories positing that consciousness is tightly linked to or identical with mechanisms of attention.

Name: Bounded Rationality
Description: A theory of decision-making suggesting that rationality is limited by available information, cognitive limitations, and time.

Name: Categorical Framework
Description: The use of category theory to provide a formal language and structure for modeling a scientific domain.

Name: Computational Theories of Consciousness
Description: Theories that model consciousness as a specific type of computational process implementable on a suitable machine.

Name: Ecological Psychology
Description: An approach to perception, originating with J.J. Gibson, that emphasizes the direct perception of environmental information (affordances).

Name: Embodied Cognition
Description: A theoretical stance that mind and cognition are fundamentally shaped by the features of the body and its interactions with the world.

Name: Evolutionary Psychology
Description: A framework that explains psychological traits as functional products of natural selection.

Name: Extended Mind Thesis
Description: The claim that cognitive processes can extend beyond the brain and body to include parts of the external environment.

Name: 4E Cognition
Description: A broad theoretical approach viewing cognition as Embodied, Embedded, Enactive, and Extended.

Name: Global Neuronal Workspace Theory
Description: A neuroscientific theory proposing that consciousness arises from the global broadcasting of information to multiple cognitive systems via a specific neural network.

Name: Integrated Information Theory
Description: A mathematical theory proposing that consciousness is identical to the amount of integrated information (Phi) generated by a system's causal structure.

Name: Implicit Processing Models
Description: Theories that investigate cognitive processing that occurs without subjective awareness or conscious report.

Name: Mathematical Theories of Consciousness
Description: Approaches that use formal mathematical structures to define and model consciousness.

Name: Memory Models
Description: Theories that explain perceptual phenomena, like change blindness, in terms of the architecture and limitations of memory systems (e.g., iconic, working).

Name: Methodological Frameworks
Description: Conceptual work that proposes specific methods or principles for how to scientifically study a phenomenon.

Name: Neural Correlates of Consciousness (NCC)
Description: The research program focused on identifying the minimal neural mechanisms jointly sufficient for any specific conscious percept.

Name: Predictive Processing
Description: A framework viewing the brain as a prediction engine that constantly minimizes the error between its predictions and incoming sensory signals.

Name: Process Theory
Description: A categorical framework, often used in quantum mechanics, that models systems in terms of processes with inputs and outputs.

Name: Recurrent Processing Theory
Description: A theory by Victor Lamme suggesting that phenomenal consciousness arises from recurrent (re-entrant) processing in the visual cortex, independent of attention or report.

Name: Sensorimotor Theory of Perception
Description: The theory that the act of perceiving is constituted by the agent's mastery of sensorimotor contingenciesâ€”the regularities between actions and resulting changes in sensory input.

Name: Structuralist Theories of Consciousness
Description: Theories that aim to explain consciousness by identifying a formal or mathematical structure that is isomorphic to the structure of phenomenal experience.

Name: Topos Theory
Description: An advanced branch of category theory that generalizes set theory and logic, used to create models of reality.

Name: Access Consciousness
Description: The state wherein information is poised for free use in reasoning, rational control of action, and verbal report.

Name: Consciousness of Action
Description: The subjective experience of initiating, executing, and controlling one's own voluntary actions.

Name: Affordances
Description: The opportunities for action that an environment offers to an agent, as perceived by that agent.

Name: Change Blindness
Description: The surprising failure to notice a large change between two visual scenes, typically when the change is obscured by a brief interruption.

Name: Change Detection
Description: The cognitive process of identifying a difference between two or more stimuli presented at different times.

Name: Choice Blindness
Description: The failure to notice a mismatch between one's intention and the outcome of one's choice.

Name: Cognitive Access
Description: The process by which phenomenal content becomes available to cognitive systems for tasks like memory, report, and decision-making.

Name: Cognitive Phenomenology
Description: The subjective, experiential character of cognitive states, such as thinking, believing, or understanding.

Name: Consciousness Science
Description: The scientific field of study of consciousness as a whole.

Name: Conscious Universe
Description: The metaphysical idea that consciousness is a fundamental and ubiquitous feature of the universe.

Name: Extended Cognition
Description: An instance of a cognitive process that physically extends beyond the boundary of the organism into the environment.

Name: Free Will
Description: The capacity of agents to choose between different possible courses of action unimpeded.

Name: Inattentional Blindness
Description: The failure to perceive an unexpected stimulus that is in plain sight, purely as a result of a lack of attention.

Name: Intersubjectivity
Description: The psychological relation between people, encompassing shared experiences and mutual understanding.

Name: Machine Consciousness
Description: The potential for consciousness to exist in artificial, non-biological systems.

Name: Olfaction
Description: The sense of smell and the subjective experiences associated with it.

Name: Perception-Action Coupling
Description: The tight, bidirectional link between what an agent perceives and the actions it can perform.

Name: Phenomenal Consciousness
Description: The subjective, experiential quality of mental states; what it is like to have an experience (e.g., seeing red).

Name: Phenomenal Variation
Description: The idea that the subjective character of experience can differ between individuals even when observing the same stimulus.

Name: Qualia
Description: Individual instances of subjective, conscious experience, considered as ineffable and private.

Name: Quantum Consciousness
Description: A class of theories proposing that quantum mechanical phenomena are essential for explaining consciousness.

Name: Social Cognition
Description: The cognitive processes that facilitate social interaction, such as understanding others' intentions, emotions, and beliefs.

Name: Veridical Perception
Description: Perception that accurately reflects the true state of the external world.

Name: Visual Memory
Description: The cognitive system responsible for retaining information about visually perceived stimuli.

Name: Visual Processing
Description: The sequence of steps the brain takes to interpret and make sense of visual information from the eyes.

Name: Conceptual Analysis
Description: A philosophical method of breaking down concepts into their constituent parts to gain clarity and understanding.

Name: Computational Modeling
Description: The use of mathematics and computer simulations to model and test hypotheses about a system.

Name: Experimental Design
Description: The process of planning a scientific experiment to test a hypothesis, including control of variables.

Name: Formal Modeling
Description: The use of rigorous mathematical or logical systems to represent and analyze a domain.

Name: Literature Review
Description: A systematic survey and synthesis of scholarly work on a particular topic.

Name: Methodological Critique
Description: An analysis that evaluates the methods, assumptions, and validity of a research study or program.

Name: Neuroimaging
Description: A set of techniques (e.g., fMRI, EEG) used to produce images of the structure or function of the nervous system.

Name: Neuroscience Experiment
Description: An experiment involving the direct measurement or manipulation of the nervous system to test a hypothesis.

Name: Phenomenology
Description: A philosophical approach that emphasizes the study of subjective experience and consciousness from a first-person perspective.

Name: Psychophysics
Description: A set of methods that quantitatively investigates the relationship between physical stimuli and the sensations and perceptions they produce.

Name: Attention
Description: The cognitive process of selectively concentrating on one aspect of the environment while ignoring other things.

Name: Embodiment
Description: The role the body plays in shaping the mind and cognitive processes.

Name: Information
Description: A fundamental concept referring to that which reduces uncertainty; central to many theories of consciousness.

Name: Intentionality
Description: The property of mental states (e.g., beliefs, desires) of being directed at or about objects or states of affairs in the world.

Name: Mind
Description: The set of faculties including consciousness, perception, thinking, judgment, and memory.

Name: Neural Correlates
Description: The specific patterns of neural activity that are associated with a particular mental state or conscious experience.

Name: Panpsychism
Description: The philosophical view that consciousness, mind, or soul is a universal and primordial feature of all things.

Name: Process Philosophy
Description: A philosophical tradition that emphasizes becoming and dynamics over static being.

Name: Representation
Description: An internal cognitive symbol or state that stands for an external reality.

Name: Time
Description: The indefinite continued progress of existence and events in the past, present, and future regarded as a whole.

Name: Multidimensional Model of Consciousness
Description: A composite, multilevel, and multidimensional model of consciousness used as a heuristic framework to guide research in artificial consciousness.

Name: Artificial Consciousness
Description: Subjective awareness in a human-designed artificial system.

Name: Awareness
Description: The capacity of a subject to process information, store it in short-term memory, and possibly intentionally retrieve it from long-term memory if needed.

Name: Intentional Action
Description: The intentional use of information for achieving goals.

Name: Multidimensional Heuristic Model of Consciousness
Description: A composite, multilevel, and multidimensional model of consciousness used as a heuristic framework to guide research in artificial consciousness.

Name: Avian Consciousness
Description: Consciousness as it exists in birds.

Name: Subjective Experience
Description: The first-person perspective and qualitative feel of conscious experience.

Name: Delayed Detection Task
Description: A task where a stimulus is presented, followed by a delay, and then a response is required.

Name: Neural Activity
Description: The electrical and chemical activity of neurons in the brain.

Name: Two-Stage Process of Awareness
Description: A model where awareness involves an initial stimulus-driven stage followed by a report-driven stage.

Name: Centrencephalic System
Description: The centrencephalic system is a brainstem system that is functionally supra-cortical in the sense of occupying a superordinate position relative to the cerebral cortex in functional or control terms.

Name: Action Selection
Description: Action selection is the process of choosing between different actions.

Name: Target Selection
Description: Target selection is the process of choosing a target for action.

Name: Motivation
Description: Motivation is the process that initiates, guides, and maintains goal-oriented behaviors.

Name: Selection Triangle
Description: The selection triangle is a novel principle relating target selection, action selection, and motivation to one another, as a means to optimize integration for action in real time.

Name: Anencephaly
Description: Anencephaly is a condition in which a baby is born with an underdeveloped brain and an incomplete skull.

Name: Hydranencephaly
Description: Hydranencephaly is a condition in which the cerebral hemispheres are absent and replaced by cerebrospinal fluid.

Name: Absence Seizures
Description: Absence seizures are a type of seizure that involves a sudden lapse in awareness, sometimes with staring or blinking.

Name: Sprague Effect
Description: The Sprague effect is the restoration of visual orienting behavior after midbrain lesions in animals with prior cortical lesions.

Name: Oscillatory Coherence Theory of Consciousness
Description: Consciousness arises from the dynamic coupling of coherent neuronal oscillations, enabling integration, structuring, selection, and communication of relevant signals.

Name: Neuronal Oscillations
Description: Rhythmic fluctuations in the electrical activity of neuronal populations.

Name: Neuronal Coherence
Description: The synchronization of neuronal oscillations across different brain regions.

Name: Multiple Generator Hypothesis
Description: The Multiple Generator Hypothesis proposes a distinction between principles and generators of consciousness.

Name: Joint Determinant Theory
Description: Joint Determinant Theory posits that consciousness is fundamentally pluralistic, and different conscious contents do not rely on one underlying consciousness-generating mechanism.

Name: Integrative Pluralism
Description: Integrative Pluralism aims to resolve conflicts between theories using multiple levels of analysis.

Name: Measure Centrality Index
Description: Measure Centrality Index aims to enable fruitful inter-theory classification that can systematically help evaluate and compare theories.

Name: Inference to the Best Explanation
Description: Inference to the Best Explanation is a method of comparing theories based on Bayesian updating and accommodated to track the relations between theories and data.

Name: Criteria-based Approach
Description: A criteria-based approach evaluates theories against a set of criteria, with the theory that satisfies the most criteria being preferable over the others.

Name: Accelerating Research on Consciousness
Description: Accelerating Research on Consciousness deploys a methodology guided by the principle of falsification combined with adversarial collaboration.

Name: Hot Topics
Description: Hot topics are specific cases where novel findings, interpretations, methodology, or conceptual arguments for a time dominate the debates in the field.

Name: Cold Cases
Description: Cold cases are instances where empirical evidence has been proposed for or against theories, but which have received little attention.

Name: Replication Crisis
Description: The replication crisis refers to the apparent number of cold cases in consciousness research.

Name: Arousal Inhibitory Mechanism
Description: An arousal inhibitory mechanism (AIM) actively transfers the brain from wakefulness to sleep.

Name: Cyclical Alternating Pattern
Description: At sleep onset in the human brain, periodic arousal changes have long been recognised, referred to as the cyclical alternating pattern (CAP).

Name: Total Consciousness
Description: Total consciousness is defined as continuous awareness of the external and internal environment, both past and present, together with the emotions arising from it.

Name: Thalamo-cortical Integrating Mechanism
Description: The electrical activity of the brain may arise from a global mechanism in the thalamus and cortex.

Name: Theory Comparison
Description: A method for comparing theories of consciousness to ensure meaningful comparisons, focusing on parallel or contrasting predictions.

Name: Theoretical Comparison
Description: The act of comparing different theories to determine which best predicts and explains empirical data.

Name: Formulating Multiple Hypotheses
Description: A method involving the creation of multiple alternative hypotheses to account for a phenomenon.

Name: Strong Inference
Description: A formal approach to operationalize a theory, test it, and compare it to alternative views.

Name: Essential Positions
Description: Core features or criteria that a theory of consciousness should account for.

Name: Philosophical Theories
Description: Foundational philosophical arguments and thought experiments concerning the nature of mind and consciousness.

Name: Attention (as a phenomenon)
Description: The phenomenal experience of selectively concentrating on one aspect of the environment while ignoring other things.

Name: Memory
Description: The faculty of the brain by which data or information is encoded, stored, and retrieved when needed.

Name: Emotion
Description: A complex psychological state involving subjective experience, physiological response, and behavioral or expressive response.

Name: Self-Awareness
Description: The capacity for introspection and the ability to recognize oneself as an individual separate from the environment and other individuals.

Name: Phenomenal Consciousness (unprefixed)
Description: The subjective, experiential quality of mental states; what it is like to have an experience. (Entry to fix evidence file typo).
